intro: Cerastium ciarcanense, commonly known as the Ciarcan's mouse-ear, is a low-growing perennial plant native to parts of Eastern Europe. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its small, hairy leaves and clusters of white flowers. The plant typically thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its flowers bloom in early summer, attracting various pollinators like bees and flies. Cerastium ciarcanense is often found in rocky or calcareous soils, showcasing its adaptability to specific ecological niches.
